articles.title: As Supreme Court takes up homeless ban, a city's unhoused feel abandoned
articles.author: Reis Thebault
articles.excerpt: A consequential Oregon case, opening Monday, will decide whether governments can enforce laws against people sleeping outside when they have nowhere else to go.
articles.summary:
GRANTS PASS, Ore. — Laura Gutowski pitches her tent in the same park where her son grew up playing Little League Baseball. Johnaton Babb's favorite place to sleep is a few feet from the river where his twin brother died when they were teenagers.
They are two among hundreds of people living outside in this small, conservative city in Southern Oregon's Rogue Valley, wedged between the Siskiyou and Coast mountains, and their experiences are part of an escalating humanitarian crisis.
among hundreds of people living outside in this small, conservative city in Southern Oregon's Rogue Valley, wedged between the Siskiyou and Coast mountains, and their experiences are part of an escalating humanitarian crisis.
Advertisement
That fact does not make Grants Pass exceptional, especially in the American West, where soaring housing costs and a collage of other causes have driven a growing number of vulnerable residents into homelessness. Even so, Grants Pass now finds itself in a unique position: This city of 40,000 will have a chance to shape policy decisions countrywide when it defends its anti-camping regulations in front of the U.S. Supreme Court on Monday.
The case will decide whether governments can enforce laws against people sleeping outside when they have nowhere else to go. The decision, expected in late June, could be the most consequential ruling on the rights of the unhoused in decades, and either sanction or derail increasingly punitive efforts across the country that seek to deal with homelessness.
More than 60 government entities large and small — from Honolulu to Maryland to the United States Department of Justice — along with dozens of advocacy organizations, academics and lawmakers, have filed court briefs in the case, underscoring the widespread interest in the outcome and its potentially sweeping implications for the nation's state capitals and city streets.
But in the public parks of Grants Pass, where residents with no access to shelter beds take refuge in tents each night, the case is about something much more elemental: Whether they'll be able to continue to survive in a city many have called home for most of their lives.
'It wasn't that long ago that I was part of the community,' said Gutowski, sitting at a picnic table in a park about a mile from her old house. 'But the more I'm out here, the more angry I get. … They're not trying to make things better for us, or help us have another shelter, or keep us safe — or help us even medically or mentally. They're just trying to push, push, push until we give up and say, ‘Fine, I'll leave town.''
A political paralysis
The events that sparked the Grants Pass case unfolded with little fanfare.
events that sparked the Grants Pass case unfolded with little fanfare.
In 2013, city leaders convened a roundtable meeting to address complaints from businesses and residents about increased crime they blamed on the local unhoused population, which they said had spiked after steep budget cuts reduced jail capacity. Officials floated a range of responses, including compiling a 'most unwanted list' that would exclude homeless people who break the law from social services and loading offenders onto a bus and shipping them out of town, according to a copy of the meeting's minutes.
Following the roundtable, the city began strictly enforcing measures, most of which were already on the books, that outlawed sleeping or camping in public spaces like parks and in parked cars, imposing fines ranging from $75 to $295 that increase substantially when unpaid and that could eventually result in jail time or a park ban. That sparked an initial legal complaint, which was filed in 2018 on behalf of Debra Blake, Gloria Johnson and John Logan, three unhoused individuals, who said the city was punishing them unconstitutionally 'based on their status of being involuntarily homeless.'
sparked an initial legal complaint, which was filed in 2018 on behalf of Debra Blake, Gloria Johnson and John Logan, three unhoused individuals, who said the city was punishing them unconstitutionally 'based on their status of being involuntarily homeless.'
Just as the city stepped up enforcement, its population soared and housing construction fell behind. Over the past decade, the city has built roughly half the number of units it needs to house everyone, said Doug Walker, a member of the Grants Pass Housing Advisory Committee. The average rental price for a studio apartment hovers around $1,000 per month.
to house everyone, said Doug Walker, a member of the Grants Pass Housing Advisory Committee. The average rental price for a studio apartment hovers around $1,000 per month.
'The homeless crisis is a symptom of the housing crisis,' Walker said. 'We have very little housing and the housing we do have is very expensive, and that drives people onto the street.'
The most recent reliable estimate puts the number of unhoused Grants Pass residents at more than 600, with another 1,000 living on the edge of homelessness, but local service providers say at least twice as many are homeless.
Making matters worse, Grants Pass does not have a homeless shelter. Its only large-scale transitional housing program, the Gospel Rescue Mission, is a privately run religious facility with 138 beds and stringent requirements for participants, such as twice-daily chapel attendance and abstinence from substances and romantic relationships.
The mission's executive director, Brian Bouteller, supports the city's position in the case because he believes an outright camping ban will drive more people into the organization's program and off the street. Allowing unhoused people to stay in the parks, he said, was akin to enabling unlawful behavior. He said he would also welcome additional, privately funded shelters in the city.
'I believe that lawbreakers should be coerced into being law-abiding citizens,' Bouteller said.
In 2020, a district court judge sided with the unhoused individuals behind the lawsuit and barred the city from enforcing its anti-camping ban in parks at night if no other shelter was available. Grants Pass Mayor Sara Bristol said the ruling plunged the city into political paralysis.
Bristol said if it were up to her, the city would spend less time fighting this legal battle and more time building new housing and shelters. But that decision rests with the city council, she said, and a majority has wanted to push ahead with the case. The council president, Vanessa Ogier, declined to comment and directed questions to the city's legal representatives.
Advertisement
Grants Pass residents have also opposed proposed locations for new shelters and outdoor campsites, and some backed a recall petition that unsuccessfully sought to oust Bristol over her handling of the crisis. A neighborhood watch group has continued to raise alarms about conditions in the city's cherished green spaces.
At one park on a recent Saturday, parents combed a baseball diamond for drug paraphernalia before their kids took the field and recovered several used needles, said Grants Pass police chief Warren Hensman.
'What we're seeing from a lot of people in the unhoused community,' Hensman said, 'is we have this unpredictable behavior' when individuals are using drugs or experiencing a mental health episode.
Bristol, for her part, said she knows the situation in the parks is untenable, which is why, no matter what the Supreme Court decides, she wants the city to build more shelters fast.
'I want our public spaces to be safe and clean and used as they were intended,' Bristol said. 'And I also want to make sure that homeless people have a place where they can be safe and sleep and get help if they want to get help. And I think we can have both, but not everybody thinks that.'
High legal stakes
The Supreme Court agreed to weigh in on this case after hearing pleas from an unlikely coalition that spanned the political spectrum, including liberal standard-bearers such as California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) and officials in deep-red states such as Montana and Alabama. Their legal briefs described governments overwhelmed by the scale and complexity of the problem: Across the country, more than 600,000 people are homeless, according to federal data, and nearly half sleep outside.
deep-red states such as Montana and Alabama. Their legal briefs described governments overwhelmed by the scale and complexity of the problem: Across the country, more than 600,000 people are homeless, according to federal data, and nearly half sleep outside.
In most places, there are not enough shelter beds to accommodate everyone who needs one. That gap between the need for services and their availability is at the heart of the Supreme Court case. Lawyers for the homeless residents say the Grants Pass laws violate Eighth Amendment protections against cruel and unusual punishment when applied to individuals who have no access to shelter.
'This combination of ordinances makes it unlawful for people to live outside on every inch of public property in Grants Pass 24 hours a day,' said Ed Johnson, the director of litigation at the Oregon Law Center and lead attorney for the plaintiffs. 'It's terrible policy, it's morally wrong and it's unconstitutional.'
Advertisement
Johnson has insisted that state and local officials are still free to restrict tents in public spaces, clear encampments and even fine homeless people who decline other shelter options, which some do for a range of reasons. The issue, he said, is when a city punishes people who have no alternatives.
Meanwhile, the Grants Pass legal team has maintained that fines and short jail terms for camping on public property are neither cruel nor unusual, but instead are tools used by governments throughout the country to preserve public spaces and protect public health.
'These laws are essential to running a city, and cities across the country, as well as the federal government, rely on camping laws just like the ones in Grants Pass,' said Theane D. Evangelis, the city's lead attorney. If the court were to rule in favor of the plaintiffs, she said, 'cities across the country would find their hands tied as they work to address the urgent homelessness crisis.'
In a legal brief filed in advance of the oral arguments, the Biden administration charted something of a middle path. Solicitor General Elizabeth B. Prelogar told the court that anti-camping laws are unconstitutional when they target homeless people who have no access to indoor shelter.
But Prelogar urged the justices to return the case to the lower courts to ensure that the city's laws are not blocked across the board. Such bans should still be allowable, she argued, if an investigation shows that a given person does in fact have access to shelter.
Garrett Epps, a law professor at the University of Oregon, said he expects a majority of the court to be sympathetic to the city's arguments, but cautioned that the justices could issue a more narrow decision than Grants Pass is advocating.
A ruling that allows cities wide discretion to pass restrictive homelessness laws, Epps said, could touch off 'a race to the bottom,' where neighboring localities pass increasingly severe policies to drive unhoused residents into other jurisdictions.
'The stakes in that sense are pretty high,' Epps said. 'Anybody who lives out here understands how important this issue is and how important the precedent being tested here is.'
Small victories
Cassy Leach is a near-constant, indefatigable presence among the unhoused in Grants Pass. Just about every day, the former emergency room nurse goes from park to park, checking in on everyone living there. She has become a Swiss Army knife for the community — there when they need laundry, groceries or Narcan; a job reference, a ride across town or a good laugh.

She has become a Swiss Army knife for the community — there when they need laundry, groceries or Narcan; a job reference, a ride across town or a good laugh.
Leach helped launch the Mobile Integrative Navigation Team, known around the city as MINT, in 2022 to help fill gaps in services for those experiencing homelessness.
'We just try to adapt to whatever the community need is at the time, and it's clear, in Grants Pass, it's a safety net,' Leach said. 'They have nothing.'
Last month, the city council tried to restrict organizations like MINT from operating in the public parks, but Bristol, the mayor, vetoed the measure. Unhoused residents say the city has become hostile, even dangerous. People camping in parks report waking up often to the sound of revving trucks and drivers screaming profanity-laced tirades, telling them to 'get a job,' 'get out of our parks' or to 'go die.'
Police recently announced they had arrested an 18-year-old 'vigilante' who had been roaming one park, shaking tents and yelling. When one unhoused woman emerged from her tent, the suspect hit her in the face with a thick tree branch, authorities said.
Advertisement
Many homeless people in Grants Pass have strong ties to the area — like Gutowski, whose family moved to the city when she was 10. She grew up loving the outdoors and she raised her own children here.
After her husband died of a pulmonary embolism in 2021, Gutowski, now 55, found herself without a job or savings. She wound up living in her car, until that broke down and she moved outside, traversing the often muddy landscape with her walker.
Gutowski said she understands the community's frustration over the condition of the parks. But like so many, she said, she has no other option. Gutowski has been trying desperately to secure subsidized housing. She's on more waiting lists that she can track.
'This is our home. This is where we have to be,' she said. 'Otherwise we're going to be on your sidewalks, in the doorways of your businesses, in the alleyways. We're going to be more visible to people driving through town.'
At Baker Park, less than a mile north of Gutowski's tent, Babb, 52, was walking along the Rogue River on a recent drizzly afternoon, still processing his father's death that week. It was a similar event — his mother's death a couple of years earlier — that spiraled him into addiction and homelessness.
death a couple of years earlier — that spiraled him into addiction and homelessness.
But this park — the site of another family tragedy decades ago, when Babb's brother died after leaping off a tall bridge into the river below — now brings him peace. When he's here, he feels closer to his late twin.
Babb isn't optimistic about the Supreme Court case — the court, like his hometown, is a conservative place, he said.
'As soon as the spotlight's gone, it's just going to go back to business as usual,' Babb said. 'And business as usual was don't ask, don't tell, let's just pretend they don't exist.'
Instead, these days, he's focusing on what he calls 'small victories.' Replacing his lost Social Security card: Small victory. Learning to put a park's address, rather than its name, on his state-issued ID so it wouldn't be immediately obvious to potential employers he was homeless: Small victory. And setting aside some time each day to write: Small victory.

On the Hill
Welcome to the bipartisan governing coalition
If it wasn't obvious before, it's obvious now.
The House's governing coalition has been cemented. It consists of nearly every Democrat and about half of Republicans.
The pattern was reinforced this weekend with a vote to pass Ukraine aid, but it has played out over and over again this Congress with the passage of major pieces of legislation.
The Republican majority has been unable to unite around must-pass bills and has thus repeatedly relied on Democrats to push bills past the finish line.
Advertisement
This weekend's vote on $60 billion for Ukraine: 112 Republicans opposed it. (Every Democrat voted for it.)
Vote earlier this month on extending FISA provisions: 88 Republicans opposed it. (Fifty-nine Democrats opposed, as well.)
March vote to fund about three-quarters of the government: 112 Republicans opposed it. (All but 22 Democrats supported it.)
Early March vote to fund a quarter of the government: 83 Republicans opposed it. (All but two Democrats supported it.)
November vote to extend government funding: 93 Republicans opposed it. (All but two Democrats supported it.)
June vote to lift the debt limit and set spending caps: 71 Republicans voted against it. (Forty-six Democrats opposed it.)
June vote to lift the debt limit and set spending caps: 71 Republicans voted against it. (Forty-six Democrats opposed it.)
The group of Republicans who have joined with Democrats is slightly different each time, but the pattern is the same. What holds the coalition together is a desire to avoid government shutdowns and, in the case of the Ukraine and FISA votes, a commitment to traditional national security priorities.
'House Democrats have risen to the occasion. President Biden has risen to the occasion. Traditional conservatives led by Speaker Mike Johnson have risen to the occasion,' House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.) said, touting the bipartisan coalition ahead of Saturday's passage of four national security bills.
President Biden has risen to the occasion. Traditional conservatives led by Speaker Mike Johnson have risen to the occasion,' House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.) said, touting the bipartisan coalition ahead of Saturday's passage of four national security bills.
How we got here
When Republicans took the majority after the 2022 midterms, they had grand ambitions of a conservative takeover of government.
But the reality is, they had just a narrow five-vote majority (twhich has shrunk to one seat with retirements and special election losses). Democrats also control the Senate and the White House.
Advertisement
Some hard-right House Republicans have tried to ignore that reality. They defeated procedural rules, a tactic that was nearly unheard of until this Congress. They kicked out one speaker and are threatening another for daring to pass bills with big bipartisan majorities.
'This is a sellout of America,' said Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.), who is leading the effort to depose Johnson from his job as speaker.
Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.), who is leading the effort to depose Johnson from his job as speaker.
It has left many more centrist Republicans or those who don't support the burn-it-down tactics frustrated.
Rep. Blake Moore (R-Utah) says Republicans would get more conservative legislation if they didn't sabotage their own process.
Rep. Blake Moore (R-Utah) says Republicans would get more conservative legislation if they didn't sabotage their own process.
'That's the part I wish every American can get. That by pretending to be super conservative, by taking down a rule and fighting the establishment … the outcome is, you have less conservative legislation. So that's okay for you individually. It's not better for the country,' Moore said.
Former House speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) had a similarly narrow coalition last Congress, when she passed major bills with consequential policy changes. But she kept her caucus united — which might have been easier because the Senate and the White House were in Democratic hands, too.
Former House speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) had a similarly narrow coalition last Congress, when she passed major bills with consequential policy changes. But she kept her caucus united — which might have been easier because the Senate and the White House were in Democratic hands, too.
Historical precedent
The coalition of Democrats and Republicans that have come together over the past year to pass spending bills and Ukraine aid in some ways echoes the 'conservative coalition' of Republicans and southern Democrats who wielded influence in the 1950s and 1960s, according to Robert X. Browning , director of the C-SPAN archives and a professor at Purdue University .
Robert X. Browning, director of the C-SPAN archives and a professor at Purdue University.
Advertisement
The alliance blocked much of President John F. Kennedy 's agenda, for instance, forcing him make concessions to get legislation passed even though Democrats had huge nominal majorities: 264 seats in the House and 64 seats in the Senate.
President John F. Kennedy's agenda, for instance, forcing him make concessions to get legislation passed even though Democrats had huge nominal majorities: 264 seats in the House and 64 seats in the Senate.
'Mr. Kennedy does not yet have a stable and loyal majority of moderate-to-liberal Democrats' in Congress, the New York Times reported in 1961
After Kennedy's death, President Lyndon Johnson managed to overcome the coalition much of the time, helped by the even larger majorities Democrats won in both chambers in the 1964 elections. The conservative coalition gradually crumbled as the parties became more ideologically uniform in the 1990s and early 2000s.

How Johnson found his coalition
ICYMI: Read about how Speaker Johnson (R-La.) evolved on Ukraine, by Leigh Ann and our colleague Marianna Sotomayor . He never voted for a Ukraine funding bill except for the very first one shortly after Russia's invasion. Now, just six months after his unlikely elevation to speaker of the House, Johnson has pushed through a $60 billion effort to bolster's Ukraine arsenal, along with funding for Israel and the Indo-Pacific.

The speaker's torturous path to embracing Ukraine aid is the result of many factors: high-level intelligence briefings as a House leader, his faith, the counsel of three committee chairs named Mike, and a realization the GOP would never unite on Ukraine.

Read the full story here.
What happens next for Ukraine aid
The Senate was supposed to be in recess this week, but it will come back Tuesday to take up the House-passed national security package that provides funding for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan and humanitarian aid for Gaza and elsewhere.
The Senate must vote again because of differences in the two chambers' bills. The House turned a portion of the Ukraine funding — the 20 percent that goes directly to the Ukrainian government — into a loan, and the House passed a fourth bill that seizes Russian assets and would ban TikTok if it isn't sold by its Chinese parent.
Advertisement
While the House passed the four parts separately, the bills are combined into one in the Senate. It will hold a vote Tuesday at 1 p.m. to move on the measure.
The earlier package received 70 votes in February. The vote tally this week should be similar.
What happens next on that effort to oust Johnson
The House adjourned for the week without Greene trigging her motion to remove Johnson from the speakership. She continues to insist that she will do it but hasn't provided a timeline.
Based on her comments, it appears she doesn't have widespread support beyond the definitive other two Republicans who have signed on: Reps. Thomas Massie (Ky.) and Paul Gosar (Ariz.).
Reps. Thomas Massie (Ky.) and Paul Gosar (Ariz.).
'My colleagues have not heard the message,' she said Saturday. 'I'm looking forward for them to go home and hearing from folks back at home.'
What we're watching
At the White House
Biden is heading to Prince William Forest Park in the Virginia suburbs to mark Earth Day.
Advertisement
On Tuesday, he'll go to Florida to give a campaign speech about abortion days before the state's six-week ban is set to take effect.
Biden has another campaign event in Washington on Wednesday.
We'll be watching how the president talks about abortion — a subject he has been hesitant to discuss in the past that is now at the center of his reelection campaign — while he's in Florida. We're also curious whether he'll make any commitment to investing in the state, which Donald Trump won in 2020.
Donald Trump won in 2020.

'The decision, expected in late June, could be the most consequential ruling on the rights of the unhoused in decades, and either sanction or derail increasingly punitive efforts across the country that seek to deal with homelessness.'

articles.title: Can Pornhub be ethical?
articles.author: Hallie Lieberman
articles.excerpt: The internet's most reviled site was a place rife with sex crimes. Now, lawyer and former rabbi Solomon Friedman is attempting to rebrand Pornhub as a 'safe space.'
articles.summary:
The internet's most reviled site was a place rife with sex crimes. Now, a lawyer and former rabbi is attempting to rebrand it as a 'safe space'
LOS ANGELES
Solomon Friedman is addressing a standing-room-only crowd in Hollywood, rooster-printed socks peeking out from his New Balance sneakers from his perch onstage.
'I come from a big Jewish family. I've had some raucous Passover Seders … but what we have in common, and we as an industry have in common, is this fundamental belief that we have a right to exist,' he says.
Friedman isn't referring to antisemitism, but pornography. After all, he's giving a keynote address at one of the biggest porn conferences in the world: the XBIZ show.
The audience visibly begins to relax, their heads nodding in agreement. Performer Melody Melons, clad in pink pants and a tight shoulder-baring black top, sits rapt.
Last year, Friedman, 38, co-founded a private equity firm to purchase MindGeek, the parent company of Pornhub, one of the largest porn streaming and entertainment sites in the world. He attended XBIZ to introduce himself to a skeptical audience whose livelihoods were initially wrecked by the site's free content offerings. After his keynote, when asked if he planned to attend the convention's lingerie-themed Wonderland party, he replied no. 'Who wants to see this,' he told The Washington Post, pointing to himself, 'in silk pajamas?'
Friedman, a lawyer who is also trained as a rabbi, is an unlikely face of Pornhub, which offers free, usually short, adult videos classified by content to 130 million daily visitors, according to the site. He speaks with the confidence and clarity of a college professor because he is one at the University of Ottawa. He certainly looks the part with his black-rimmed glasses, closely cropped beard and gray sport coat.
according to the site. He speaks with the confidence and clarity of a college professor because he is one at the University of Ottawa. He certainly looks the part with his black-rimmed glasses, closely cropped beard and gray sport coat.
Advertisement
Pornhub is wildly popular, monopolistic and disruptive — as well as one of the internet's most reviled sites. It was one of the first adult 'tube sites,' like YouTube, where anybody could upload clips, resulting in a site rife with child porn, rape and sex trafficking. The company faces opposition from all corners: state legislators, international governments, anti-trafficking groups, credit card companies and the adult entertainment industry itself. The company was so disliked that its previous owner's house was burned down. Friedman said he has received death threats and that he and his three kids have been subjected to 'horrific antisemitism.'
The company faces opposition from all corners: state legislators, international governments, anti-trafficking groups, credit card companies and the adult entertainment industry itself. The company was so disliked that its previous owner's house was burned down. Friedman said he has received death threats and that he and his three kids have been subjected to 'horrific antisemitism.'
And so Friedman wants to reform Pornhub, he said, with plans to compensate performers more fairly, keep nonconsensual material off the site, and vet studios and performers more closely. The company's recent press materials speak of 'core values of consent' and describe it as 'a safe space for verified content creators.' It also touts its 'supportive partnership' with a national social justice network for sex workers. Critics remain skeptical.
'I don't think that there is any other … product where the gulf between private consumption and public criticism is so broad,' Friedman told The Post. 'The people that don't like guns, they don't secretly have big vaults full of guns.'
Porn has been decried as a public health crisis, with age verification laws, which are supposed to prevent kids from accessing online porn, sweeping the nation. Eight states now require some form of official ID, such as a driver's license, or commercially available information such as mortgage data, to access online porn; five more have passed similar laws that will go into effect by Jan. 1, 2025; and at least 16 states have bills requiring ID pending. The Texas legislature even passed a law requiring porn websites to include a controversial warning that 'pornography is potentially biologically addictive' and 'proven to harm human brain development.'
Pornhub has fought back against these laws. The company was a co-plaintiff in a lawsuit against the state of Texas, arguing that the state's age-verification law was unconstitutional. In March, a judge ruled that the law could stand, but struck down the warning requirement. Now, the company blocks access to Pornhub in Texas, as they do in Virginia, Montana, North Carolina, Arkansas, Utah and Mississippi.
One of Pornhub's most outspoken opponents is the National Center on Sexual Exploitation (NCOSE), formerly Morality in Media. In a Jan. 25 press release, NCOSE said despite new ownership, Pornhub 'is likely still infested with videos of rape, sex trafficking, child sexual abuse.' NCOSE is a co-plaintiff in two lawsuits against Pornhub's parent company (filed before Friedman bought MindGeek), alongside a woman who had videos of her being sexually abused as a child posted to the site. Another group, the religious anti-porn organization Exodus Cry, has created TraffickingHub, a website and campaign aimed at shutting down Pornhub, claiming the site profits from child abuse and sex trafficking.
Advertisement
Not all critics of Pornhub are anti-porn. The #NotYourPorn group — founded when a woman's hacked iCloud videos ended up on Pornhub — got the site to remove numerous nonconsensual videos in 2019, but only after months of campaigning. The group's director, Elena Michael, thinks Pornhub can redeem itself by implementing new safety policies, but she wants the company to apologize publicly for harming victims. 'We have expressed regret,' Friedman said, pointing to a previous company statement.
Michael, thinks Pornhub can redeem itself by implementing new safety policies, but she wants the company to apologize publicly for harming victims. 'We have expressed regret,' Friedman said, pointing to a previous company statement.
Pornhub also has few friends within the industry. Its original business model was ripping off copyrighted content, streaming it on its website free and raking in cash from advertising. People stopped paying for porn. Eventually, Pornhub gave performers and directors a way to monetize their content, but the damage was done.
'It was an absolute disaster for the porn industry,' said sex worker Cherie DeVille, who spoke on the condition that The Post use only her stage name for safety reasons. 'Their entire business model, like Napster back in the day, was to steal. … The first time Pornhub came to AVN [another porn conference] people spat on them.'
A few hours before his keynote, Friedman is standing by the water dispensers at the Kimpton Everly Hotel bar, far from the busty BongaCams girls bouncing pink and white balloons. He appears to be figuring out his place in all of this, though he smiles and laughs easily. Still, he's prepared to talk, occasionally resorting to sound bites and repeating phrases such as 'trust and safety' and 'constitutionally protected.'
For Friedman, porn isn't the problem. It's just that it peels away social niceties to reveal the human condition. 'Pornography is a mirror and reflects society back at itself,' he said. 'So when people complain about porn, it's like looking in the mirror, being unhappy [and saying], ‘I gotta smash that mirror.''
Friedman, who was one of nine kids, grew up 'in a house with more computers than children,' he said. His dad was a computer programmer, and Friedman had a Unix terminal in his bedroom. Friedman followed a typical Orthodox Jewish path: he married young, had three kids and studied Torah. He moved to Israel to attend rabbinical school at age 18. After returning to Canada, he became ordained as a rabbi, then went to law school. Friedman clerked for the Supreme Court of Canada, then became a criminal defense lawyer in private practice, a job he held for 15 years.
Dominic Lamb, Friedman's friend and former law partner, said that when Friedman joined the firm Edelson and Associates in the early 2010s, he was 'a super bright young man' and a 'hustler' with 'a great business mind.' Friedman was particularly skilled at teaching and mentoring young lawyers, Lamb said. The two worked on a number of child pornography cases. 'It gives you a nuanced sense of how the legitimate world of pornography works … and where things go wrong,' Lamb said. In 2019, Friedman left to create a law firm with Fady Mansour.
Ironically, it was Nicholas Kristof's scathing December 2020 op-ed in the New York Times, which argued that exploitation and assault were endemic to Pornhub, that put the site on Friedman's radar. About three months after the article was published, Bruinen Investments, which was trying to acquire MindGeek, brought Friedman on board as a partner to assess the company's criminal and regulatory compliance. He'd read Kristof's article and said he was predisposed to think the company was a possible cesspool. 'In a million years, I never thought that I would have anything to do with an adult entertainment company,' Friedman said.

He'd read Kristof's article and said he was predisposed to think the company was a possible cesspool. 'In a million years, I never thought that I would have anything to do with an adult entertainment company,' Friedman said.
But Pornhub was using 'probably the most sophisticated content fingerprinting tool' to find and eradicate child sexual abuse material, Friedman said. 'As a defense lawyer involved in cases with respect to online exploitation … [I learned] how difficult it is for … mainstream social media platforms to block unlawful content and how difficult it is for police to investigate and ultimately prosecute these offenses,' Friedman said.

The company may be public enemy No. 1, but social media sites remain the biggest distributors of child sexual abuse material (CSAM). According to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, in 2022, Facebook self-reported 21,165,208 instances of suspected CSAM in comparison to Pornhub's 1,996. These reports are required by law.

The initial acquisition failed. Then, last year, Friedman set up a private equity firm with Mansour, his law partner; political strategist Sarah Bain; investor Rocco Meliambro; and Derek Ogden, the former chief superintendent of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The group, which has members with ties to Canada's cannabis industry, was named Ethical Capital Partners (ECP) — an audacious moniker given the porn industry's reputation — and bought MindGeek for an undisclosed sum, renaming it Aylo. (According to Toronto's the Globe and Mail, Bruinen had been prepared to pay $475 million for a 'distressed' Pornhub in 2021.)

Lamb wasn't surprised by the move. Though the company was controversial, Lamb said, as a former criminal defense lawyer, Friedman was used to dealing 'with baggage.' He thinks Friedman's experience will allow him 'to bring a fresh set of eyes … so that those who are engaged in pornography as a business can make money and that nobody is going to get hurt.'
Later on at a 'Meet Market' event, Friedman stood next to a palm tree and an open bar on the fifth-floor patio of the hotel, surrounded by buxom content creators in sky-high heels, goateed directors and gold-jewelry-clad business executives, all vying for his attention. He had become the star of the show, although he maintained he was there to listen.
The next day, Friedman gives up his seat to an older attendee and stands next to the exit sign to listen to Pornhub executive Sana Gaziani and the company's vice president of community and brand, Alex Kekesi, speak. They're updating a packed room on Pornhub's newest services — the TikTok-like video streamer Shorties and an OnlyFans competitor called UVIU — as well as increasingly stringent verification requirements for performers.
Pornhub doesn't want kids anywhere near porn for ethical reasons, Kekesi tells the crowd, her cherry red nails and studded clogs betraying her punk-rock past. And the company isn't 'against age verification in principle.' But the laws are 'ineffective and designed to kill our industry,' she insisted. Kids can use virtual private networks (VPNs) to get around restrictions. She prefers device-level verification, which Apple and Android phones offer, where parents can use built-in controls to block pornography.
The mood shifts when Gaziani projects a slide about the company's new performer verification requirements, which spark several complaints about onerous paperwork. Everyone in a scene must be verified, not just the performer who uploads the video. 'We want to make sure everybody's over 18 [and] the IDs … match the individuals in the videos,' Gaziani said. If the content doesn't have people's faces in it, 'sometimes we ask for a full-body scan,' she continued. 'We're doing it in the name of safety. We're not trying to make anyone's life more difficult.'
A lack of verification is what got Pornhub into trouble before. Kristof's piece condemned the Wild West-like nature of Pornhub, which allowed anyone to upload videos. In response to the article and U.S. and Canadian government investigations, '8 million pieces of unverified content were removed,' Friedman said. And Pornhub started the verified upload program.

After the conference, Friedman would conduct a walk-through of it over Zoom. 'We're now up to about 35,000 forbidden words [and] phrases in 32 languages,' he said of the program, which also checks IDs for authenticity, running them through a known fraud list, and requires facial scanning. One group Friedman works with is Crime Stoppers International (CSI). 'You go where the risk is, and if there's an organization that's looking to reduce harm to children online, then we're all for it,' said Shane Britten, CSI's director. 'They [Pornhub] go through a far more rigorous check than YouTube or Facebook.'
What Friedman is most proud of is the Safeguard program. It provides digital fingerprints for each item on the site. When content is flagged for CSAM, nonconsensual videos or terms-of-service violations, Safeguard fingerprints it, prevents the video from being uploaded, and searches the 4.5 million videos on the website for copies.
The user side has been amped up as well. At the bottom of every page of Pornhub is a 'content removal request form.' If someone fills it out, the video gets taken down immediately.
Pornhub doesn't offer AI-generated adult videos, and while it does use AI for moderation and safety, every piece of content goes through human moderation as well, according to Friedman. Pornhub has 'always considered deep fakes to be nonconsensual content' and the company is 'at the forefront of combating them,' he said. The Taylor Swift deepfakes that 'spread like wildfire' on social media, he added, 'never would have passed even the most basic cursory review by a Pornhub moderator.'
Advertisement
Just how significant are these reforms? Samantha Cole, a journalist who focuses on sex work and technology and is the author of 'How Sex Changed the Internet and How the Internet Changed Sex,' said that Pornhub is 'one of the very few online platforms that's actually made meaningful changes to the way it operates following criticism.' Though she believes it is now 'the safest tube site on the internet,' the company hasn't always been this way.
'People working directly in the industry — including employees of Pornhub as well as performers themselves — urged the company to make meaningful moderation changes for years, to stop content theft as well as nonconsensual abuse imagery,' she said. 'Corporations almost always put profit over safety, and are usually reactive instead of proactive when it comes to moderation. Pornhub was forced to act following a serious blow to its business [Mastercard, Visa and Discover pulling services from the site] due to an intense anti-porn and ‘anti-trafficking' campaign.'
Others are harsher in their assessment. Becky Holt, a PhD candidate at Concordia University who is writing her dissertation on Pornhub's history and content moderation policies, said that the company's rebranding is nothing new. 'It feels very familiar to me in terms of language. … I've seen the company go through a pretty similar cycle,' she said. 'I remain skeptical, I guess, of what they mean when they say ‘ethical.''
'They will make significant changes under the banner of ethics, if it's something that seriously impacts their profit,' Holt continued. This includes preventing kids from accessing the site, she added. 'There's a lot of evidence to suggest that they've always been extremely careful about content featuring minors … because this could shut down their business … but it's very, very hard to do the kind of proper level of nitpicking that you really need to do in order to find this type of content.'
Aylo, meanwhile, has another audience to convince: the dozens of state senators who think the company shouldn't exist. On March 14, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R) tweeted: 'Pornhub has now disabled its website in Texas … good riddance.'
Montana state Sen. Willis Curdy (D) told The Post that he didn't expect Pornhub to block access to his state after the age-verification bill he sponsored became law on Jan. 1, 2024. He said he sponsored the legislation because he believes access to porn websites has led to sexual assaults and suicides. Pop singer Billie Eilish's claim that 'watching porn destroyed my brain' also influenced his decision. His bill was modeled on Louisiana state Sen. Laurie Schlegel's (R) age-verification bill, the first in the nation, which went into effect Jan. 1, 2023.
'I got bipartisan signatures on the bill. And it sailed through both the House and Senate,' Curdy said. 'This is not a party issue. It's a human health, a human psychology, issue.'
The rebrand does, however, appear to be working within the adult entertainment industry itself. When it was announced that Mastercard had resumed processing payments on the site, a cry of 'Hallelujah!' could be heard from the conference crowd.
'I really liked the fact that they're willing to put a face to the name out there and talk to regulators or talk to government officials. I think that's absolutely critical. It opens the door ... to say, ‘Hey, this is a legitimate business,'' said Jimmy James, COO and VP of adult video company ATKingdom, adding that the new leadership is 'potentially removing the stigma' of the adult industry.
The conference 'went better than expected,' Friedman said on its final day. He was standing in the hotel restaurant holding a bag full of business cards. 'This is a tough industry … but being here re-energized me. You meet the real human beings,' he said.
He felt welcomed. And he was optimistic about his mission. Pornhub's executives 'share the very same values of the general public,' he insisted. 'We want to respect people's bodily autonomy. We want to protect young people. We cherish freedom of expression, individuality and sexuality. There's a reason why adult content is constitutionally protected in every single Western liberal democracy.'
